item.title: Sort string array by string lengths
item.dc:creator: @k00dr k00dr
item.description:
@k00dr wrote:

[quote=“Bang Train, post:6, topic:152532”]i just put

for(int i = 1; i < arr.length; i++) {
if(arr[i-1].length() > arr[i].length()) {
String s = arr[i-1];
arr[i-1] = arr[i];
arr[i] = s;
}
}

into a while(!sorted)

and made a loop to check if it was in order or not[/quote]

Bang Train:

but is this really the best method?

No, it certainly is not.

frank_:

http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/util/Arrays.html#sort(T[],%20java.util.Comparator)

This is

Moparisthebest:

I’m not sure what algorithm Java uses.

If I remember right, it uses bubblesort on shorter arrays and quicksort on longer ones.

item.title: Sort string array by string lengths
item.dc:creator: @Bang_Train Bang Train
item.description:
@Bang_Train wrote:

i just put

for(int i = 1; i < arr.length; i++) {
if(arr[i-1].length() > arr[i].length()) {
String s = arr[i-1];
arr[i-1] = arr[i];
arr[i] = s;
}
}

into a while(!sorted)

and made a loop to check if it was in order or not

item.title: Sort string array by string lengths
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Sorting arrays a staple of computer science, there are perhaps thousands of sorting algorithms, all with their own distinct advantages and disadvantages. Bubble sort, insertion sort, and selection sort are some of the first, simplest examples that you are taught, merge sort, quick sort, and heap sort are some of the more advanced ‘faster’ ones. (speed depends on input, selection sort can be much faster than quick sort on almost-sorted data for example)

So decide what your input will look like, and then write an algorithm to do what you want.

Alternatively, be lazy and use frank_'s method I’m not sure what algorithm Java uses.

Read full topic

item.title: Sort string array by string lengths
item.dc:creator: @Bang_Train Bang Train
item.description:
@Bang_Train wrote:

Ya…google was no help too many words that occur in too many places…

Sooo i need to sort a string array by the length of the strings

ex:
before:

aaa
aa
aaaaaa

after:
aa
aaa
aaaaaa

ive been told this:

for(int i = 1; i < arr.length; i++) { if(arr[i-1].length() > arr[i].length()) { String s = arr[i-1]; arr[i-1] = arr[i]; arr[i] = s; } } and to iterate it a few times, but is this really the best method?

Read full topic
